docs.lead_paragraph: Rolando Grullon's little playmates do not understand why he yells at them so often. When the preschoolers are in a group, laughing, playing or just talking, they are startled when Rolando, just 3 1/2, turns angry and aggressive. ''It's not that he's mad at them,'' said Rolando's mother, Isabel Pichardo. ''He's just frustrated, because he can't hear them.''

headline.main: Hearing a Little Boy's Cry of Pain, a Mother's Cry of Despair

docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; Isabel Pichardo discusses how Health Care Access Program enabled her son, Rolando Grullon, to have operation for hearing problem; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Feb. 10 front-page article about Britain's National Health Service didn't mention a key factor in the difficulties faced by Jackie O'Donnell, a British cancer patient who had to pay for chemotherapy out of her own pocket. It was the pharmaceutical company that supplied the drug she needed, using the monopoly conferred by patent protection, that set the price at $16,000. Similar practices have priced AIDS therapy beyond the reach of most of the world. Less critical is the situation in which recent billion-dollar drugs for less severe conditions are in the ''blockbuster'' category because of high protected prices, not the numbers of prescriptions.
docs.abstract: Art Hilgart letter on Feb 10 article blames monopoly conferred by patent protection for high cost of drugs British cancer patient had to pay for herself

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''G.O.P. Senate Leaders Back Bill on Insuring Infertility Treatments'' (news article, Feb. 8): The New York State Senate has recognized the responsibility of insurance companies to cover infertility treatments, yet the senators block pending legislation to require insurers to cover birth control. Most women spend much of their lives trying to avoid unintended pregnancy, often paying hundreds of dollars each year.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''In Britain's Health Service, Sick Itself, Cancer Care Is Dismal'' (front page, Feb. 10): The British specialty service for cancer care was hit hard by severe underfinancing that began in the 1980's. But the overall health of Britain's population has remained excellent, due in large part to excellent primary care and universal coverage. The United States has the opposite problem: enormous resources are consumed by profit-making and administrative costs in a largely private medical care system. Public health services are underfinanced, and 44 million people are uninsured.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Victor W Sidel (Public Health Association of New York City) on Feb 10 article holds Britain offers excellent primary medical care and universal coverage; urges United States to reform its wasteful private medical system

docs.lead_paragraph: Last year, the Senate and House approved vastly different patients' rights bills. After months of delay, a conference committee will meet later this month to reconcile the differences. It is crucial that any compromise bill apply to all insured Americans and give them a meaningful right to sue health plans for damages incurred when care is improperly denied. The two bills differ greatly in the number of people covered and their right to sue. The excellent House bill, sponsored by Charlie Norwood and John Dingell, would cover all 161 million Americans who have private insurance. It would also change federal law to permit patients to sue their health plans in state courts under state laws. This strong measure was approved by an impressive bipartisan vote of 275 to 151 and has White House support. Most of the provisions of the weaker Senate bill, by contrast, would apply only to the 48 million Americans in ''self-insured'' plans that are exempt from state regulation. The Senate bill provides no right to sue.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges House-Senate conference committee to reconcile difference on patient bill of rights so that final legislation applies to all insured Americans and gives them meaningful right to sue health plans for damages incurred when care is improperly denied (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jon S. Corzine has spent the last several months learning the difference between office politics and politics. In his previous line of work, at the investment firm of Goldman, Sachs, where he served as chairman and C.E.O. until early last year, Corzine was counted a master politician -- the kind of executive who understood the secret ambitions and fears of everyone around him. On Wall Street, being a good politician had a lot to do with being likable. Now, however, Corzine is running for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in New Jersey, a state whose politics do not typically reward amiability. Corzine's opponent is Jim Florio, the former governor of the state and a man who is, for good reason, invariably referred to as ''an ex-boxer.'' Last month, according to a news account, Florio fired his media adviser when the adviser refused to follow Florio's ''scorched-earth policy.'' One day last month, I sat with Corzine through an interminable ceremony marking the opening of the 209th session of the New Jersey Legislature. During a lull between the skirling of the bagpipes and the nomination of the clerk of the Assembly, Corzine handed me a copy of a Florio news release. Like a number of leading Democrats, Corzine advocates investing up to 15 percent of the Social Security Trust Fund in the stock market. In the release, Florio not only claimed that Corzine was threatening the stability of Social Security -- arguable, though fair game -- but also went on to declare that the proposal was ''clearly in Jon Corzine's self-interest'' since Goldman and other Wall Street firms would benefit from the trading activity. That was a low blow. Corzine whispered: ''He's saying that I'm going to benefit from this personally. That just makes no sense.'' Corzine was plainly scandalized, though a less self-contained person might have found a more vehement way of expressing it.

headline.main: What's a Nice Liberal Multimillionaire Doing In a Race Like This?

docs.abstract: James Traub article on Jon S Corzine, multimillionaire former chairman of Goldman Sachs who is running for Senate in New Jersey; Corzine, 53-year-old Illinois native known as unusually decent person in Wall Street's tough world, is taking on Jim Florio in even tougher business of New Jersey politics; Corzine is also unabashed liberal who is almost certainly to left of entire US Senate, opposing welfare reform and mandatory sentencing and favoring affirmative action; adviser Susan Estrich comments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House passed a Republican-sponsored bill last week that would give a big tax cut to all married couples -- even those who are benefiting from the existing tax code and not suffering at all from the so-called ''marriage penalty.'' The G.O.P. points to married couples who, under the current code, pay more in tax than they would as two unrelated individuals. That penalty, say the Republicans, amounts to an unconscionable attack on marriage. But what the Republicans gloss over is the fact that the tax code also provides a bonus to many other married couples. Indeed, over 40 percent of married couples pay less tax than they would as separate individuals. Yet the G.O.P. bill hands them an additional tax cut anyway. About half of the total tax reduction would go to families already enjoying a tax bonus. This scattershot approach would eventually cost about $30 billion a year -- more than President Clinton proposes to spend on a drug benefit for Medicare and nearly half as much as Bill Bradley wants to spend on health insurance.

headline.main: A Bloated Tax Cut for Marriage

docs.abstract: Editorial opposes House-passed bill to end 'marriage penalty' in tax code, since about half of the total tax reduction would go to families already enjoying a tax bonus; says this scattershot approach will eventually cost the Treasury $30 billion a year; favors more focused alternatives for dealing with marriage penalty proposed by Pres Clinton and Gov George W Bush

docs.lead_paragraph: Donovan Byfield remembers the job in Chelsea, where the door to the apartment opened and the owner's German shepherd charged in and bit him as he was laying carpet. He remembers how, during the four years he installed floor coverings for ABC Carpets, the home furnishing chain with its main store at Broadway and 19th Street, up to 25 percent of his pay went into an escrow account to cover any damages he might cause and to pay for workers' compensation, a total of $21,000, he said.

headline.main: A Former Rug Installer Takes On ABC Carpet
headline.kicker: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE

docs.abstract: Former carpet installer Donovan Byfield files class-action federal suit against former employer asserting ABC Carpet failed to compensate workers for overtime, called them independent contractors while treating them like employees and failed to return monies placed in escrow account that would have been used to cover damages (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman whose doctor carved his initials into her skin after he delivered her baby by Caesarean section has settled a lawsuit against the doctor and dropped her claim against Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, the hospital said yesterday. Under the terms of the settlement, the patient, Dr. Liana Gedz, a dentist, will receive $1.75 million, according to people who were involved in the settlement talks.

headline.main: Patient Settles Case Of Initials Cut in Skin

docs.lead_paragraph: A lot rests on just a few. Of the nearly 11 million registered voters in New York State, 3 to 11 percent of them tell pollsters that they have not yet made up their minds about the race for United States Senate. The figure is surprisingly small this early in an election campaign, perhaps because the two candidates, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton, are celebrities.

headline.main: The Calculus Of Voter Support; For Some, Politics of Senate Race Come Second to Personal Concerns

docs.abstract: Article in series on US Senate race in New York State focuses on 3 to 11 percent of registered voters in state who have not yet made up their minds about race; says figure is surprisingly small this early in election campaign, perhaps because two candidates, Rudolph Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton, are celebrities; some undecided voters discuss their decision-making as campaign unfolds; graphs; photos (M)
